headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Sept. 21-22, 2019

headline: Pence: More Deregulation on the Way
summary: And new hope for expanded trade.

headline: Fed Mulls Lessons of Money-Market Spike After Curbing Volatility
summary: Federal Reserve officials are studying whether market plumbing issues contributed to a spike in short-term lending rates this week.

headline: Trump Says He Wants ‘Complete Deal’ With China
summary: President Trump dismissed the trade war as “a little spat” and rejected the notion of accepting a partial trade agreement, saying Beijing’s plan to boost purchases of U.S. agriculture exports alone isn’t enough.

headline: Photos of the Week
summary: GM workers go on strike, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau apologizes for wearing brownface, Tropical Storm Imelda inundates parts of Texas and more from The Wall Street Journal’s photo editors.

headline: U.S. Grants Apple 10 Exemptions from Tariffs on Chinese Imports
summary: The Trump administration has given Apple a reprieve from tariffs on 10 items, including a power supply and a logic board, that are imported from China.

headline: The Real Cure for Inequality
summary: Income gains are now rising faster for low-wage workers.

headline: Judicial Make-Up Call
summary: With two more Trump nominees, Patrick Bumatay and Lawrence VanDyke, this isn’t Obama’s Ninth Circuit.

headline: The Lawyer Enrichment Act
summary: Will Republicans be snookered by an anti-arbitration bill?

headline: Photos: Thousands March in Global Climate Protest
summary: Around the world people have taken to the streets to call on politicians to take action on climate change.

headline: YouTube CEO Apologizes Over Verification Changes
summary: YouTube’s Chief Executive Susan Wojcicki has apologized for concerns over the decision to remove the verification status of its content creators.

headline: House Passes Bill to Establish Whistleblower Program at Audit Regulator
summary: PCAOB Whistleblower Protection Act of 2019 proposes to establish a whistleblower program at the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board that will be similar to the whistleblower program at the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Deadly Floods in Texas Revive Memories of Hurricane Harvey
summary: For East Texas residents like James Revia still recovering from devastating Hurricane Harvey two years ago, tropical depression Imelda brought flooding they thought they would see only once in a lifetime.

headline: ‘Hustler’: How a Scam Artist Became a Diligent Go-Getter
summary: From the late 1600s to the hit movie with Jennifer Lopez, the hard-working term has straddled the border between legality and illegality.

headline: ‘Surfacing’ Review: The Past is Ever Present
summary: Kathleen Jamie’s new essay collection has two principal themes: the degree to which the natural world is full of vivid juxtapositions—and our tendency to overlook them because we’re distracted by the ephemera of everyday life.

headline: Political Books: Interpreting Clarence Thomas
summary: How to grapple with the justice’s unique judicial thought, rather than dwell on his biography.

headline: Boeing to Compensate Icelandair for 737 MAX Grounding Costs
summary: Icelandair said it reached an agreement for Boeing to cover costs associated with the airline’s six grounded 737 MAX jets—one of the first carriers to disclose such a settlement since the planes stopped flying in March.

headline: Crude Prices Inch Lower, but Post Weekly Gains
summary: Brent crude futures, the global benchmark, fell slightly on Friday, but still notched their best week since January as investors remained uneasy about supply disruptions following attacks on Saudi Arabia’s oil facilities.

headline: The Glass Ceiling
summary: Despite being one of the most prolific and famous living composers, Philip Glass’s work is rarely performed by major American orchestras.

headline: Whistleblowers Dealing in Classified Information Present Legal Dilemma
summary: At the heart of an legal showdown over an anonymous whistleblower’s complaint concerning President Trump is a law designed to allow members of the intelligence community to bring forward evidence of wrongdoing by the government.

headline: U.S., El Salvador Reach Deal on Asylum Seekers
summary: The Trump administration reached a deal with the government of El Salvador to send some asylum seekers from third countries back to El Salvador, in the latest effort to dissuade migrants from entering the U.S. illegally.

headline: Why Trump Is Winning on Iran
summary: The U.S. should focus on sanctions while letting the Saudis cope with any nasty local spillovers.

headline: A Woman Doesn’t Need an Office to Be Empowered
summary: A patient told me: ‘I feel pressured to leave my children and return to meaningful work.’

headline: Frontier Communications, Creditors Prepare for Debt Restructuring Talks
summary: Frontier Communications is telling bondholders that it will shortly present a detailed plan to slash its $17 billion debt load, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: How Pittsburgh Became the Monongahela Miracle
summary: Planners nearly killed Steel City, but ‘eds,’ ‘meds’ and market-based development have given it new life.

headline: Facebook Suspends More Apps, Tightens Data Controls
summary: Facebook said it suspended tens of thousands of apps for violating its rules around accessing and sharing information, a disclosure that follows the company’s record $5 billion fine from federal regulators in July.

headline: Led by California, States Sue DOT Over Tailpipe-Emissions Dispute
summary: California, joined by 22 other states and the District of Columbia, sued the Trump administration to preserve the state’s power to set tougher vehicle-emissions standards for the auto industry.

headline: Cloud Adoption Is Slowed by People as Much as Technology
summary: People issues can hinder a company’s move to the cloud just as much as technological hurdles, three finance and asset-management technologists said at an industry event

headline: Hess, General Motors, Amazon: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: U.S. stock benchmarks fell on the week; here are seven of the biggest companies whose stocks moved on news.

headline: Stocks Turn Lower at the End of a Bumpy Week
summary: Major U.S. stock indexes broke a three-week winning streak, closing with a modest loss after a volatile stretch in the markets.

headline: Xandr President to Leave Unit as  Its Bond With WarnerMedia Tightens
summary: The president of AT&T’s Xandr is leaving the advertising and analytics unit as it begins to operate more closely with WarnerMedia , according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Chip Maker Xilinx Searches for New CFO to Help Lead Expansion
summary: Chip maker Xilinx is looking for a new finance chief to help lead its expansion into new markets and boost revenue for its data-center and automotive businesses, the company said.

headline: Walmart to Stop Selling All E-Cigarettes
summary: Walmart will stop selling all e-cigarettes in its U.S. stores, citing regulatory uncertainty around the vaping devices after the White House announced plans to ban most flavors.

headline: Ex-CEO’s Suit Against Vista-Backed Solera Tossed Out
summary: Solera, which makes software for the automotive and insurance industries, faced accusations by its former Chairman and Chief Executive Anthony Aquila that the company was trying to deny him vested stock options after he left the company in May.

headline: Quadruple Witching Brings Volatility
summary: Stock volatility had fallen in recent days. But turbulence picked up Friday as a flurry of derivatives were set to expire.

headline: New England Patriots Release Antonio Brown
summary: The New England Patriots released star wide receiver Antonio Brown after less than two weeks with the team, after multiple women accused the receiver of sexual misconduct, including one allegation of rape.

headline: Barron Hilton, Son of Hotel Chain’s Founder, Escaped Father’s Huge Shadow
summary: Barron Hilton resisted early pressure to join the hotel company created by his father, Conrad Hilton, but eventually led Hilton Hotels Corp. into the Las Vegas casino business.

headline: Distressed Debt Trading Overshadows Corporate Bond Market
summary: A sharp rally in the bonds of three distressed companies—McDermott International, California Resources and PG&E—dominated trading in the corporate bond market.

headline: Travel Operator Under Pressure to Raise Additional Funds
summary: Troubled British travel company Thomas Cook Group is under pressure from lenders to find an additional £200 million ($249.5 million) to avoid the collapse of a rescue deal that would see Chinese conglomerate Fosun International Ltd. inject significant funds.

headline: The Mind vs. Brain, Is There a Difference?
summary: The mind is more than the sum of its neuronal connections.

headline: Mighty Nimby Fights Building New Housing
summary: Higher density—turning every American city into a poor copy of Manhattan Island—isn’t the solution to our housing problem.

headline: Trudeau Tries to Pivot Away From Controversy Over Blackface Images
summary: After two days of apologies over photos showing him wearing blackface, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau tried to pivot election-campaign talk toward gun control with a promise to ban military-style assault rifles and give cities the power to ban handguns.

headline: Hearing Aids Can Assist With More Than Speech
summary: A telecoil connects hearing aids wirelessly to induction hearing loops that transmit sound from public-address systems, stages, church pulpits and lecture halls as mandated by the Americans with Disabilities Act.

headline: GM Furloughs Workers in Canada as Strike Drags On
summary: General Motors has furloughed roughly 2,000 hourly workers at a plant in Oshawa, Ontario, near Toronto, as the impact of a strike by the United Auto Workers in the U.S. ripples north.

headline: Trump Picks Matt Pottinger as Deputy National Security Adviser
summary: President Trump has chosen one of his leading policy counselors on China and North Korea as his new deputy national security adviser, according to an administration official.

headline: Lawmakers Propose Bill On Bankruptcy Case Location
summary: Lawmakers have introduced a bill to require companies filing for bankruptcy to do so in a court near their headquarters—which would help direct filings away from bankruptcy hubs in New York and Delaware.

headline: Salad Chain Sweetgreen’s Tech Focus Helps Push Valuation to $1.6 Billion
summary: Investors are putting another $150 million behind Sweetgreen, betting that the salad restaurant chain’s embrace of technology will deliver them an exit in a sector that has seen minimal venture activity in recent years.

headline: Grad Students to Lose Unionization Rights Under NLRB Rule
summary: Graduate students, who often teach the bulk of university classes, would lose their status as employees and their rights to join a union, under a proposed rule approved by the National Labor Relations Board.

headline: Are Bar Carts as Great As Instagram Thinks?
summary: Darlings of social media, the boozy trolleys are quite divisive. We explore both sides of the debate.

headline: Intense Humanity and Musical Genius
summary: George Gershwin’s compositional brilliance and DuBose Heyward’s deeply affecting narrative combined to turn ‘Porgy and Bess’ into an iconic American opera.

headline: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio Exits Democratic Presidential Race
summary: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio dropped out of the Democratic presidential race Friday after his long-shot campaign failed to gain traction with voters.

headline: Apple’s Challenge for iPhone 11: Halt Sales Slide in China
summary: As Apple’s iPhone 11 models goes on sale world-wide, they face their biggest challenge in China, Apple’s second-largest market, where new cameras and lower prices aim to help stanch sales declines.

headline: Pace of Growth Slowed for U.S. Household Net Worth in Second Quarter
summary: The net worth of American households grew in second quarter, but at a slower rate than the prior quarter.

headline: Fed Officials Explain Dissents From Rate Cut
summary: Two Federal Reserve officials explained why they opposed this week’s interest-rate cut, and a third defended the move, as central bankers remained split amid an uncertain outlook for the economy.

headline: Robbie Robertson Misses His Brothers in The Band
summary: In a new album and documentary, the legendary songwriter reflects on the influential group’s dissolution.

headline: Fed’s Rosengren Says Cutting Rates Now Boosts Risk of Instability
summary: Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren said cutting rates now may boost the risk of financial instability, which could make the next downturn more severe when it comes.

headline: A Unifying Israeli President Looks to Break Election Impasse
summary: The task of breaking Israel’s election deadlock falls to President Reuven Rivlin, a grandfatherly national figure who has called for unity but faces an uphill battle as all sides dig in.

headline: Twitter Suspends Former Saudi Official Linked to Khashoggi Killing
summary: The social-media company revealed a fresh round of account suspensions, including one used by a former top Saudi official, as Twitter continued its efforts to curb coordinated disinformation on its platform.

headline: General Motors Strike Unleashes Frenzy of Options Trading
summary: Volumes on GM options hit the highest level since July on Thursday, with some investors bracing for extreme moves in the stock.

headline: McLaren GT: Introducing the World’s Most Civilized Supercar
summary: Evolving from the pavement-scraping speed demons McLaren has always unleashed, the new GT-series of cars will be the first into which one can fit a golf bag. Columnist Dan Neil drives the suburban supercar to Cannes.

headline: Democrats and Republicans Live in Different Worlds
summary: Are you a Democrat or a Republican? The answer depends heavily on your income, your job and your neighborhood.

headline: Yes, to Save the World, Wisconsin Really Needs to Beat Michigan
summary: A once-ambivalent student feels the passion for his alma mater.

headline: CME Group Plans to Offer Bitcoin Options
summary: Exchange operator CME Group said Friday it planned to launch options on its bitcoin futures contracts in the first quarter of 2020, the latest move by an established market player to expand into the crypto business.

headline: Berlin Unveils Climate Package as Hundreds of Thousands Take to the Streets
summary: Germany unveiled an array of climate policies designed to curb greenhouse gas emissions that economists said were unlikely to provide much of a boost to the country’s flagging economy, despite a projected $60 billion price tag between now and 2030.

headline: An Ancient Practice Transformed by the Arrival of Europeans

headline: You’re Probably Washing Your Face Wrong

headline: ‘The Dutch House’ Review: Family Treason

headline: Fiction Review: The Forgotten Women Warriors of Abyssinia
summary: Dramatizing the tenacious resistance to Italy’s invasion of Ethiopia, Maaza Mengiste’s new novel shines light on an often-overlooked conflict.

headline: Mysteries: Hunting the Elevator Executioner
summary: In Linwood Barclay’s startling and witty thriller, someone is tampering with elevators in New York City high-rises and sending passengers plummeting to their deaths.

headline: Five Best: Sara Collins on Crime Novels
summary: From the author of “The Confessions of Frannie Langton.”

headline: James Challenger Helped Create Market for Outplacement Services
summary: James Challenger pioneered outplacement services in the 1960s for executives who lost their jobs. The early reaction from companies, he said, was why should we help people we’re firing? He died Aug. 30 at age 93.

headline: Children’s Books: Little Lords and Princesses
summary: Frances Hodgson Burnett’s novels feature imperfect, distinct characters, including children who suffer sharp reversals of fortune.

headline: Arch Rivals Quarrel Over Quirky Geological Formations
summary: Controversies abound in the world of natural-arch hunters: Are there 11 categories or 17? Tape measure or laser range finder? And about that guy who looks for them on Google Earth

headline: Fairness in Housework Doesn’t Mean 50/50

headline: Vanguard Bets on Robo-Only Adviser
summary: Vanguard Group plans to launch a robo-advisory service that cuts out human financial advisers, aiming to capture younger, tech-savvy investors.

headline: St. Greta Spreads the Climate Gospel
summary: A movement that believes in sin, penance and salvation doesn’t sound very scientific.

headline: Taiwan Loses Another Diplomatic Tie, as China Continues Isolation Push

headline: Whitey Bulger’s Family Files Claim Against Federal Government

headline: Market Calling the Clock On Tech Unicorns
summary: The clock appears to be ticking on the days in which technology companies losing billions of dollars are valued at tens of billions in the public market. That realization may be forcing the hand of today’s most richly valued private companies.

headline: Lively and Intimate Likenesses

headline: Harris Takes Risky Iowa-or-Bust Tack
summary: Sen. Kamala Harris joins the ranks of faltering presidential candidates who have gone all in on the first state to hold its nominating contest.

headline: AT&T Boss Met With Activist to Discuss Strategy
summary: AT&T’s chief executive met this week with the activist investor who is pressing the company to rethink its strategy and sell off more assets.

headline: The Disappearing Political Center: In More Places, Elections Aren’t Close
summary: For a stark illustration of how the political center is disappearing from American politics, compare President Bill Clinton’s re-election in 1996 with Donald Trump’s victory 20 years later.

headline: Stocks to Watch: U.S. Steel, Datadog, Altria, Tegna and More
summary: Datadog, Ping Identity, Steelcase, U.S. Steel, Xilinx, and Scholastic are among Friday’s stocks to watch.

headline: This Dog Will Hunt
summary: Dogs aren’t known for patience, but Datadog proved that two birds in the bush are sometimes worth waiting for.

headline: Trump, Australian Prime Minister Look to Reinforce an at-Times Strained Alliance

headline: Saudi Oil Attacks Could Halt Natural-Gas Rally

headline: Gail Simmons on Setting Boundaries with Your Money and Time
summary: Gail Simmons, the cookbook author and “Top Chef” judge tells host Veronica Dagher in WSJ’s “Secrets of Wealthy Women podcast,” she generally doesn’t invest in people she knows really well.

headline: Pulisic Is the Future of U.S. Soccer. England Isn’t Convinced.
summary: As Christian Pulisic finds his feet in the Premier League, his biggest obstacle is an army of other Pulisics, pumped out by the same European academy system.

headline: The Georgia Bulldogs Want to Wreak Havoc on Opponents
summary: As No. 3 Georgia prepares to host No. 7 Notre Dame on Saturday night, creating more havoc has become the central goal of the Bulldogs’ defense in 2019.

headline: Rest Easy: The Fed Isn’t Losing Control of Money Markets
summary: Banks’ short-term funding costs registered an alarming spike this week, but this just reflects a return to precrisis central banking.

headline: How Renée Zellweger Became Judy Garland
summary: Preparing to play the iconic performer involved throwing chairs, FaceTiming nightly with her vocal coach and staying in character on set.

headline: Goldman, China’s Sovereign-Wealth Fund Invest in U.S. Manufacturing
summary: China’s sovereign-wealth fund has started investing in the U.S. manufacturing sector through a joint venture with Goldman Sachs, but warned it would be more cautious about the American market because of the trade war.

headline: North Korea Names Nuclear Negotiator
summary: North Korea named a veteran diplomat with extensive U.S. experience as its chief negotiator for working-level talks with Washington, while praising President Trump for dismissing national security adviser John Bolton.

headline: Indian Prime Minister Modi, in Visit to U.S., Seeks to Ease Trade Tensions
summary: India may loosen restrictions impeding U.S. goods as Prime Minister Narendra Modi heads to the U.S. for a weekin an effort to damp simmering trade tensions and garner fresh investment into its flagging economy.

headline: Japan’s Mitsubishi Says Rogue Oil Trader Lost $320 Million
summary: Japan’s Mitsubishi said a subsidiary has lost about $320 million on energy derivatives, after a rogue employee in Singapore entered into secret unauthorized trades and then lost money as crude prices fell.

headline: Why Hong Kong’s Currency Is Still Rock Solid
summary: The Hong Kong government decided to peg its currency to the dollar during a time of turmoil to restore confidence. The exchange-rate system put in place then should once again weather the turmoil the city is facing.

headline: Apple’s Triple Shot May Add Some Kick
summary: By all accounts, Apple is expected to have another dud year of iPhone sales. Ironically, that may work out well for the company as its three new phones hit stores on Friday.

headline: Mastering the Art of Impatience
summary: Need better efforts on short timetables? Start by giving a damn.

headline: Are High-School Girls Really Abandoning Basketball?
summary: A long-running survey of U.S. high-school sports participation made headlines this year by reporting that participation was down for the first time in three decades. There’s some reason for skepticism.

headline: Nintendo Seeks to Sustain Switch Sales With Stripped-Down Console
summary: Nintendo introduced a stripped-down Switch console, meant to keep up the line’s momentum in its third holiday season, as the videogame maker seeks to widen the Nintendo brand’s global presence.

headline: DeVos Family Office Affiliate to Buy Stake in Nordic Capital
summary: The booming market for buyout firm stakes has a new entrant: the DeVos family office.

headline: Harris Takes Aim at a Rising Warren
summary: Democratic presidential hopeful Kamala Harris faults Elizabeth Warren’s transfer of funds from her Senate campaign, Republican advisers appear to lose to Democratic advisers in Israel’s election, and more in Washington Wire.

headline: The Unexpected Consequences of Being Too Optimistic About Growth
summary: In a slow economy, investors appear to be setting a high bar for improvements in corporate earnings. Bad things can happen when companies try to hit unrealistic targets.

headline: Powell’s Subtle Messaging to Trump on Trade Fight
summary: Fed Chairman Jerome Powell’s press conference this week carried a subtle message for President Trump: If you’re worried about an economic slowdown, find a way to cool down the trade war.

headline: U.S. Needs to Do More on 5G, Senator Says
summary: The U.S. should consider adopting Beijing’s tactics to stay ahead in the global race to deploy 5G, the next generation of wireless technology, Sen. Mark Warner (D., Va.) said.

headline: Bondholders Stranded as HNA-Backed Airport Defaults
summary: In a departure from HNA Group’s record of paying back international bondholders despite its financial constraints, an airport partly owned by units of the Chinese conglomerate has failed to repay holders of its dollar bonds on time.

summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: Donor to Pay Off Morehouse College Parents’ Debts Along With Students’
summary: Robert F. Smith, the private-equity billionaire who pledged to wipe out the student-loan debt of the class of 2019 at Morehouse College, will cover debt taken on by the students’ parents as well.

summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: A ‘Grass Roots’ Campaign to Take Down Amazon Is Funded by Amazon’s Biggest Rivals
summary: Walmart, Oracle and mall owner Simon Property Group are secret funders behind a nonprofit that has been highly critical of the e-commerce giant.

headline: What We Know About the Saudi Oil Attacks

headline: The Man Democrats Loathe More Than Trump
summary: Sen. Mitch McConnell on his high-stakes battles for the Supreme Court, his ways of cajoling reluctant colleagues, and the chamber’s future.

headline: Saudi Arabia Shows Depth of Damage to Its Oil Facilities
summary: Saudi Arabia brought reporters to see oil facilities attacked by drones and missiles last weekend, a move aimed at rallying international support against Iran ahead of a critical meeting next week of world leaders at the United Nations.

headline: Brazil Announces Criminal Charges Against Vale Employees in Dam Collapse
summary: Brazilian police announced criminal charges against Vale and its German safety auditor over the miner’s dam collapse in January, the world’s deadliest in more than half a century.

summary: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ.

headline: ‘Bosom Friends’ Review: ‘Buck’ & His ‘Better Half’
summary: Some say James Buchanan was the first gay president, pointing to his friendship with former senatorial colleague William R. King. Whatever the nature of their bond, its fruits were clear: a pro-slavery agenda that shaped pre-Civil War politics.

headline: When the Slave Traders Were African
summary: Those whose ancestors sold slaves to Europeans now struggle to come to terms with a painful legacy.

summary: From the colonial era to today, the bitter legacy of bondage and racial oppression has sparked demands for compensation, with some successes and many broken promises

headline: ‘The Second Founding’ and ‘Equality: An American Dilemma, 1866-1896’ Review: Replanting Democracy
summary: Reconstruction was only part of an effort to rebuild American society on egalitarian terms.

headline: ‘The Meritocracy Trap’ Review: Squeezing Through the Narrow Door
summary: The acquisition of status and wealth strictly on merit would seem to be a democratic ideal. In practice, a new book argues, it has been a disaster for America.

headline: ‘The Accusation’ Review: Hysteria on Main Street
summary: Little Barbara Griffiths briefly disappeared 91 years ago this week, and for the first time the “blood libel” spread through a U.S. town.

headline: ‘You Don’t Have to Face It Alone.’ Hong Kong Protests Propelled by Hidden Support Network
summary: The quiet backing of older, professional locals helps explain the longevity of the youth-led movement. Their assistance includes “school bus” rides home, protective gear and financial aid.

headline: Market for Illicit Vaping Products Flourishes Online
summary: As concerns about the health hazards of vaping mount, a market for cannabis-vaping products and the tools to create counterfeits is thriving online on big tech platforms like Amazon and Facebook.

headline: China Detains Former U.S. Air Force Pilot Flying for FedEx
summary: Chinese authorities have detained a FedEx pilot in the city of Guangzhou, elevating pressure on the company, which is already in Beijing’s crosshairs amid a U.S.-China trade war.

headline: ‘I’m Not Your Therapist.’ What’s the Point of an Executive Coach?
summary: Having your own Wendy Rhoades can be a badge of honor, but as lines blur some see problems. A big one: no legal confidentiality protection.

headline: Sanders’s ‘Revolution’ in Burlington: Working With GOP, Business
summary: Bernie Sanders’s record as mayor shows that at times he went to opponents, working with Republicans, police and business on key issues facing Vermont, sometimes to the frustration of his liberal allies.

headline: Political Control in Virginia Up for Grabs in Tight Election
summary: Democrats are making a push to win control of both houses of Virginia’s legislature in this fall’s election, reviving the governor’s gun-control efforts and positioning them for the next wave of redistricting.
